sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Carbon dots (CDs) including graphene quantum dots (GQDs), carbogenic nanodots (CNDs), and carbon nanodots (CNDs) are defined as 0D and quasi-spherical nanoparticles with sizes of less than 10 nm.[1] As a new class of emerging carbonic nanomaterials, CDs have inspired intensive attention due to their unique advantages compared with conventional semiconductor quantum dots, such as excellent photostability, biocompatibility, low toxicity, low cost, simple synthesis, water solubility, chemical inertness, and so on.[2–5] These intriguing properties afford CDs a variety of potential applications in biological, chemical, and optoelectronic fields.
Tracing back the history of CDs, it is interesting to find that CDs were accidentally discovered in 2004 during the separation and purification of single-walled carbon nanotubes using
As a new class of luminescent nanomaterials, carbon dots (CDs) have aroused significant interest because of their fascinating photoluminescence properties and potential applications in biological, optoelectronic, and energy-related fields. Strikingly, embedding CDs in host matrices endow them with intriguing luminescent properties, in particular, room temperature phosphorescence and thermally activated delayed fluorescence, due to the confinement effect of the host matrix and the H-bonding interactions between CDs and the matrix. Here, the state-of-the-art strategies for introducing CDs in various host matrices are summarized, such as nanoporous materials, polyvinyl alcohol, polyurethane, potash alum, layered double hydroxides, amorphous silica, etc. The resultant luminescent properties of the composites and their emission mechanisms are discussed. Their applications in bioimaging, drug delivery/release, sensing, and anticounterfeiting are also presented. Finally, current problems and challenges of CDs-based composites are noted for future development of such luminescent materials.
Carbon Dots
gel electrophoresis.[1] In 2006, a chemical synthetic method was proposed to produce luminescent carbon nanoparticles, which were named “carbon quantum dots (CQDs).”[6] Since then, studies of the synthesis and luminescent properties of CDs have been continuously increasing.
Generally, CDs are composed of amorphous to nanocrystalline cores with sp2 carbons, and many functional groups can be presented on their surface, such as amino, epoxy, ether, carbonyl, aldehyde, hydroxyl, and carboxylic acid groups.[1,7–9] The structures and compositions of CDs are closely related to their synthetic methods and the use of carbon sources or molecular precursors. To date, CDs have been synthesized using two classes of methods: the top-down route, in which the C-dots are broken off from a larger carbon species,[10–14] and the bottom-up route, in
which the CDs are formed from molecular precursors.[15–21] In addition, the surface passivation or surface functionalization of CDs may further enhance their physical and fluorescence properties.[22] Large-scale production of CDs has also been achieved, which provides the fundamentals for their practical applications in sensing and bioimaging.[23–29]
Photoluminescence (PL) emission is the predominant property of CDs. CDs present excitation wavelength-dependent fluorescence and excitation wavelength-independent fluorescence with different PL colors, ranging from ultraviolet (UV) to near-infrared (NIR). Recently, unique room temperature phosphorescence (RTP) and DF behaviors have been discovered because the special surface groups on CDs (e.g., CN, CO) and the interactions between CDs (e.g., aggregation, crosslinkenhanced emission) can stabilize the triplet states and promote intersystem crossing (ISC).[30–43] In particular, embedding or immobilizing CDs in various host matrices, such as polyvinyl alcohol, polyurethane, potash alum, metal–organic frameworks, and zeolites, has provided CDs with interesting fluorescence and more stability in air atmosphere.[44–71] Notably, we have developed a CDs-in-zeolite strategy to generate novel thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) composites with an ultralong lifetime due to the stabilizing effect of the zeolite matrix on the triplet states of CDs.[45] The dots-in-matrix strategy provides a new platform for developing CDs-based materials with interesting PL properties, and may further promote practical applications of CDs in bioimaging and biosensing, photocatalysis, and optoelectronics.
In the past few decades, there have been several reviews of the synthesis, physicochemical properties, surface

The state-of-the-art synthetic methods, PL properties and mechanism, and applications of such composites are presented and discussed. The intriguing luminescence properties of the composite materials, such as RTP, TADF, and multiple PL properties are highlighted. Finally, a brief conclusion and perspectives on the future developments of CDs-based composite materials are provided.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis of CDs-Based Composite Materials
sections.text: Some host matrices including polyvinyl alcohol, potash alum, polyurethane, metal–organic frameworks, mesoporous materials, and zeolites have been used to immobilize CDs to prepare CDs-based composite materials. The related synthetic methods differ according to the various CDs and the host matrix, which are summarized in Table 1. Typically, two main synthetic approaches have been used for producing CDs-based composite materials, i.e., a one-step method and a two-step method. The one-step method means that the CDs and matrix are simultaneously generated in the reaction system; thus, the CDs are in situ confined in the host matrices. The two-step method means that the CDs are prepared first using the top-down/down-top route and then embedded in the host matrices via chemical or physical methods, or the host matrix is prepared first and then further treated by combustion/pyrolysis/heating to generate CDs in it.

sections.heading: 2.1. One-Step Synthetic Method
sections.text:
In 2017, our group first demonstrated a strategy to in situ embed CDs in zeolite matrices in dots-in-zeolites system under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions.[45] A series of luminescent CDs@zeolite composites have been synthesized by changing several synthetic factors for zeolites, i.e., the organic amines and the solvents. Figure 1a illustrates the in situ synthetic approach using zeolite AlPO-5 (AFI zeotype) as an example. CDs@AlPO-5 was prepared in solvothermal system by using triethylamine as the template and triethylene glycol as the solvent. Uniform CDs (≈3.7 nm) were embedded in AlPO-5 crystals. More recently, two new CDs@zeolite composite have also been prepared by using dots-in-zeolites strategy and introducing heteroatoms into zeolite matrix under hydrothermal conditions.[46] In addition, a one-step synthesis of a CDs-based composite was also demonstrated by choosing stable Zr-MOF (UiO-66(OH)2) as the host matrix.[44] CDs were in situ generated and confined in the UiO-66 framework via a solvent-free synthesis strategy. As shown in Figure 1b, the reaction mixture including ZrOCl2·8H2O, 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (BDC-(OH)2) and tetraethylammonium bromide was ground at room temperature, and then crystallized at 180 °C to form CDs@UiO-66 composites.
Notably, the direct in situ incorporation of luminescent CDs into the host matrix is somewhat difficult to achieve due to the uncontrollability of their simultaneous generation in one
system and the requirement of a strong driving force to coassemble the guest CDs and host matrix.[53,90] Hence, thus far, the examples of one-step synthesis of CDs-based composites remain limited. The successful one-step synthesis of CDs@ zeolite composites occurs for the following reasons: (1) zeolites with well-confined nanospaces and high stability are suitable host matrices to accommodate various small functional species;[91,92] (2) the hydrothermal or solvothermal synthetic methods are feasible for the formation of zeolites and CDs; (3) the organic species (i.e., templates and solvents) used in the synthesis of zeolites provide the source materials for CDs;[93] and (4) most importantly, the simultaneous formation of CDs and zeolites can be achieved by varying the synthetic conditions. In summary, dots-in-zeolites is a facile strategy for onestep synthesis of CDs-based composite materials.

sections.heading: 2.2. Two-Step Synthetic Method
sections.text:
Compared with one-step incorporation of CDs into the host matrix, the two-step synthetic method for the fabrication of CDs-based composites is more controllable and easily achieved. More diverse host matrices including nanoporous materials (zeolites, metal–organic frameworks, mesoporous structures),

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Zeolite as the Matrix
sections.text:
Zeolites refer to the crystalline aluminosilicates or aluminophosphates with 3D 4-connected framework with uniformed pores less than 2 nm. Bourlinos et al. first used zeolites as the matrix to immobilize luminescent CDs, in which NaY (FAU) zeolite was first ion-exchanged by 2,4-diaminophenal dihydrochloride, followed by thermal oxidation to graft CDs (≈4–6 nm) onto the external surface of NaY zeolite.[47] Later, Xiu et al. reported CDs confined in MAPO-44 (CHA) zeolite via direct pyrolysis of the occluded cyclohexylamine template or the loaded additional organic molecules (acetone, ethanol, acetic acid).[48] Using the pyrolysis of organo-templated zeolites, our group prepared a series of CDs@zeolite composites by modulating the zeolite host matrix and organic templates, as well as the calcination conditions (e.g., temperature and time).[49,50] Note that the selection of a suitable zeolite host is a key for

pyrolysis of organo-templated zeolites to generate CDs. Baldovi et al. revealed that small pore zeolites ITQ-29 (LTA) and ITQ-12 (ITW) might facilitate the generation of CDs in zeolites during heating treatment, whereas medium or large pore zeolites silicalite (MFI) or pure silica Beta (*BEA) led the complete removal of occluded organic templates.[51] Due to their high thermal stability, zeolite structures are almost retained in the reported CDs@zeolite composites, but CDs should be embedded in the interrupted nanospaces or reside on the external surface of zeolite matrices due to the larger size of CDs (≈2–6 nm) compared to the diameter of micropores (less than 2 nm).

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Mesoporous Material as the Matrix
sections.text:
Mesoporous materials refer to a class of amorphous, ordered or crystalline materials with order pores of diameter size 2–50 nm. Thus, mesoporous materials are excellent host matrices to accommodate luminescent guest species, such as CDs and perovskite nanocrystals.[94–96] In 2012, Lai et al. reported the synthesis of CDs@mSiO2 and CDs@mSiO2-PEG (mSiO2 = mesoporous SiO2; PEG = polyethylene glycol) composites by mixing the as-prepared mSiO2 nanoparticles with glycerol and then capping PEG-NH2 by heating.[52] In such composites, mSiO2 acts as a nanomatrix regulating the size distribution of confined CDs, and PEG can enhance the luminescence. Using a coassembly strategy, Kong et al. successfully incorporated graphitic pencil nanodots (PNDs) (≈3 nm) into ordered mesoporous materials (Figure 2a).[53] In this method,
PNDs were first prepared from conventional graphite pencils using an electrochemical method and subsequently embedded into a variety of mesostructured materials (e.g., TiO2, silica, carbon, and silica–carbon materials) via hydrogen bonds. In addition, nonmetallic heteroatom (e.g., N, B, P, and S atoms)doped PNDs could be fabricated by preadsorption of heteroatoms followed by thermal annealing. On the other hand, using NH2-functionalized SBA-15 (SBA-NH2) as the matrix, CDs@SBA-NH2 nanocomposites were prepared using a microplasma-assisted method. The synthesis involved filling the raw materials (citric acid and ethylenediamine) into the mesopores of presynthesized SBA-NH2 and treating them with an atmosphere microplasma.[54]

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Metal–Organic Framework (MOFs) as the Matrix
sections.text:
As a new class of porous materials, MOFs constructed by metal ions/clusters and organic linkers exhibit diverse framework structures, high surface areas and variable pore sizes. Taking one classical MOF (ZIF-8) as the host matrix, several CDs@ZIF-8 composites were synthesized through a two-step method during which CDs were first prepared via a microwaveassisted method or a hydrothermal/solvothermal method, and then incorporated into the matrix by adding them into the reaction mixture of ZIF-8.[55–57] Using a similar method, N,Sdoped CDs were encapsulated into a Eu-MOF matrix.[58] In the study of Wang et al., a CDs@ZIF-8 composite was prepared by solvothermal synthesis of ZIF-8 nanocrystals followed by

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Polymer PVA and PU as the Matrix
sections.text:
The PVA is found to be an ideal candidate for preparing composite film. CDs@PVA composite film can be easily fabricated by homogeneous dispersion of as-prepared CDs into a PVA aqueous solution, followed by coating and drying/ annealing.[60–64] Such a method is very simple, in contrast to the abovementioned chemical methods for CDs-based composites. Meanwhile, a broad range of CDs obtained using different synthetic approaches can be embedded in a PVA matrix. As with PVA, polyurethane (PU) is widely used in industry and can also be used as a matrix, but the synthesis process of CDs@PU composite is more complex.[65] For example, in the work of Tian et al., N-doped CDs were prepared from isophorone diisocyanate (IPDI) as the carbon source under microwave irradiation.

sections.heading: 2.2.5. Other Matrices
sections.text: A simple physical mixing method was used to fabricate the CDs-based composite over the potash alum KAl(SO4)2·x(H2O) matrix.[66] CDs@KAl(SO4)2·x(H2O) and CDs@KAl(SO4)2 composite powders were prepared by drying a mixture of CDs aqueous solution and KAl(SO4)2·x(H2O) solution under different conditions. Li et al. further developed two-component matrices to accommodate luminescent CDs.[67] In their work, N-doped CDs were hydrothermally prepared from a folic acid precursor and were subsequently incorporated into composite matrices by heating the mixture of N-doped CDs and urea. Two different matrices were produced during the heating process, which were the melting recrystallized urea and biuret transformed from urea. Jiang et al. reported the hydrothermal treatment of CDs in colloidal nanosilica (nSiO2) solution to produce a CDs@nSiO2 composite.[68] The advantages of a colloidal nSiO2 matrix such as a high water dispersibility, optical transparency, and possible coupling reaction on the surface enables CDs to fix onto colloidal nSiO2 via strong covalent bonds. More recently, Li et al. presented the unique hydrogenbonded matrices established in the CDs@CA suspension (CA: cyanuric acid).[69] As shown in Figure 2b, CDs were prepared by heating the mixture of citric acid and urea in deionized (DI) water, followed by diluting CDs in DI water and then mixing with CA. Interestingly, the bridge-like H-bonded networks similar to matrices were formed between CDs and CA after putting CDs@CA powder in water. In addition, CDs can be embedded in the silica gel and layered double hydroxides (LDHs) matrices to generate CDs-based composites.[70,71]

sections.heading: 3. Photoluminescence of CDs-Based Composite Materials
sections.text: Photoluminescence (PL) is one of the most important characteristics of CDs and the basis of their various applications. To date, CDs of various sizes and different PL emission wavelengths ranging from ultraviolet (UV) to near-infrared (NIR) have been prepared. Intriguingly, embedding CDs in a matrix may further regulate their PL properties, and in some cases boost new luminescence properties, such as RTP, TADF, and so on.

sections.heading: 3.1. Florescence Regulation
sections.text:
Fluorescence regulation of CDs-based composites can be achieved by controlling the size and content of CDs in the host matrix. Studies show that the content of CDs in a zeolite matrix is usually determined by the thermal treatment conditions. For instance, in the case of CDs@MAPO-44, the contents of CDs were modulated from 0.24 to 1.2 wt% by decreasing the calcination time
(550 °C, 30 to 5 min) or temperature (500 °C, 5 min).[48] The emission wavelength was closely related to the content of CDs, and the higher the content was, the longer the emission wavelength would be. Hence, CDs@MAPO-44 exhibited a tunable emission color from violet to orange-red (Figure 3a).
Another feasible approach to fluorescence regulation is embedding CDs into a luminescent matrix and tuning their emission intensities by varying the content of CDs or with the aid of external stimulus. For instance, the CDs@Eu-MOF composite presented dual emissions from the blue-emitting N,Sdoped CDs and red-emitting Eu-MOF, which exhibited light of different colors in the presence of organic solvents and water (Figure 3b);[58] CDs@ZIF-8 comprised the ZIF-8 matrix with blue emission and CDs with yellow emission; thus, an approximate white light was achieved by combining these two emissions by controlling the calcination times.[59]
The third approach to realizing fluorescence regulation is mixing two or more types of CDs with different light emissions into a host matrix.[61] On the basis of the RGB color model, full color CDs@PVA composite films were fabricated by mixing and dispersing various ratios of m-CDs (red), o-CDs (green), and p-CDs (blue) in a PVA matrix (Figure 3c). The as-prepared films showed a broad range of PL emissions, and no significant interaction occurred between these three CDs in the PVA matrix. A white-light emission film with CIE coordinates of (0.33, 0.34) was obtained by mixing o-CDs, m-CDs, and p-CDs in a ratio of 2:4:1 (weight) (Figure 3d).

sections.heading: 3.2. RTP Property
sections.text:
As one of the long afterglow materials, RTP materials can absorb photons to form electronically excited states and subsequently emit light.[97] The typical RTP materials include organometallic and crystalline organic compounds.[98,99] In recent years, by combining the excellent PL property of CDs and the efficient confinement effect of various host matrices, several CDs-based composites with interesting RTP properties have been discovered (Table 2).
PVA is one of the most popular matrices for confining CDs to generate RTP composites. In 2003, the first example of a phosphorescence composite prepared by doped CDs in a PVA matrix was reported.[60] The CDs dispersed in water or in PVA film showed emissions at 400 nm when excited under 325 nm, but the CDs in a PVA matrix displayed an extra phosphorescence at 500 nm with a lifetime of 350 ms after UV light was turned off (Figure 4a–c). Later, two RTP composites with lifetimes of 450 and 8.7 ms were prepared by doping CDs and CDs in PVA and PU matrices, respectively.[63,65] More recently, thermal-treatment controlled RTP composites were discovered in which the green phosphorescence appeared in different CDs@PVA films after different thermal annealings (150 or 200 °C).[64] In addition to PVA, zeolites as the host matrix can also facilitate the production of the RTP property. For example, CDs@zeolite composites prepared by pyrolysis of organotemplated zeolites exhibited green phosphorescence and their RTP lifetimes and quantum yields were in the range of 277–312 ms and 15.3–18.3%, respectively, by tuning different zeolite matrices and guest CDs species.[50]

Another interesting study of a CDs-based RTP composite was presented for a CDs@CA composite, in which the phosphorescence of CDs@CA powder was greatly enhanced by a special matrix, i.e., water-induced H-bonding system formed between CDs and CA.[69] CDs@CA powder showed a green afterglow at room temperature with a lifetime of 253 ms. When added to water, an increased phosphorescence threefold that of the CD–CA composite was observed and the average lifetime enhanced to 687 ms (Figure 4d,e). The strongest phosphorescence was achieved with a water content of 70%, and phosphorescence disappeared with a water content greater than 98% due to the dissolving of CDs@CA composite. Furthermore, the phosphorescence of the CDs@CA suspension remained visible under UV light at the nanometer scale (Figure 4f). The ultralong phosphorescent CDs-based composites were fabricated using composite matrices (urea and biuret).[67] Among three composites with different N contents in CDs, the composite with more surface CN groups on CDs exhibited an ultralong phosphorescence lifetime of up to 1.06 s under 280 nm excitation and a high PQY of up to 7% under 360 nm excitation. Recently, a green afterglow with a lifetime of 1.8 s has been reported in a CDs@nSiO2 phosphorescence composite.[70] The RTP of CDs with a lifetime of 386.8 ms is presented in CDs@ LDHs assisted by an orderly arrangement of metals and a rigid and confined LDH layer.[71] All abovementioned CDs-based composite materials exclusively emit green phosphorescence, unlike the rare earth-based materials emitting blue, green and red phosphorescence, hence

sections.heading: 3.3. TADF Property
sections.text: The TADF materials have important applications in optoelectronic applications. The traditional TADF materials include metal–organic complexes and organic molecules.[100,101] Strikingly, several CDs-based TADF composites with ultralong lifetimes and a high efficiency were recently prepared by our group using the dots-in-zeolite strategy.[45] The asprepared CDs@zeolite composites exhibited excitationdependent fluorescence with quantum yields (QYs) varying from 15.53% to 52.14%. Taking CDs@MgAPO-5 as an example, when the UV light was turned off, a delayed luminescence was observed by naked eyes (Figure 5a). The lifetime of delayed fluorescence was up to 350 ms (Figure 5b). The delayed component increased with the temperature varying from 100 to 350 K (Figure 5c), confirming the TADF behavior of the CDs@AlPO-5 composite. The calculated energy gap between the singlet and triplet states was 0.22 eV (Figure 5d). CDs@2D-AlPO and CDs@MgAPO-5 based on different host matrices also possessed the TADF property and their lifetimes are 197 and 216 ms, respectively. Notably, the as-made CDs-based composites are very stable in air atmosphere due to the effective oxygen barrier effect of zeolite matrix, which can exhibit TADF property for more than half a year.

sections.heading: 3.4. Multiple Luminescent Properties
sections.text:
Compared to conventional luminescent materials, two or three types of emission simultaneously present in a single luminescent material are quite rare. With the aid of a PVA host matrix, triple-mode emission of CDs including PL, upconversion PL (UCPL) and RTP was achieved in m-CDs-PVA composite film.[62] The as-prepared composite film was transparent and nearly colorless, and exhibited blue PL and cyan UCPL when excited with a UV lamp (365 nm) and NIR femtosecond pulse laser (800 nm), respectively. In addition, a green afterglow of RTP was observed after the UV lamp was turned off. The lifetime of the RTP was 456 ms, which is much longer than that of PL (6.41 ns).
On the other hand, a unique long afterglow emission composed of TADF and phosphorescence was observed in the CDs@nSiO2 composite.[68] The afterglow emission spectrum of CDs@nSiO2 was identified as its steady-state PL spectrum, indicating the DF nature (Figure 6a), and its intensity became higher under an argon atmosphere (Figure 6b). Figure 6c shows a typical thermally assisted process, suggesting the TADF behavior.[102] A long afterglow lifetime (av. 0.703 s) was obtained via the decay spectrum (Figure 6d). Further study revealed that the afterglow emission had two components of TADF and phosphorescence, in which TADF was a major contribution for the

sections.heading: 4. PL Mechanism of CDs-Based Composite Materials
sections.text:
The PL mechanism of CDs is still undergoing research. Generally, eight main theories for the emission mechanism of CDs have been summarized by Sun and co-workers:[89] (1) band gap emission and the quantum confinement effect; (2) surface states emission; (3) molecular fluorophores and a carbogenic core; (4) polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon molecular emission; (5) slowed solvent relaxation or a solvatochromic shift; (6) selftrapped exciton emission; (7) a surface dipole emission center; and (8) an aggregate emission center. These mechanisms could be of guidance for various PL applications and enhanced performance of CDs materials. For the CDs-based composites, different host matrices may lead to quite distinct photoluminescence properties. This observation highlights the significant role of matrices in boosting the PL property of the CDs-based composites.
The phosphorescent mechanism of CDs in composite matrices was studied by Li et al. (Figure 7a),[67] who showed that the phosphorescence emission of CDs-based composites came from the CN bonds on the surface of CDs. Surface CN bonds could create new energy level structures and a small energy gap (ΔEST) between singlet and triplet states. Moreover, the composite matrices played a dual role in producing phosphorescence. One major role was the H-bonding interactions between CDs and biuret, which could restrict the vibrational motions of surface
CO and CN groups to protect the triplet state. The other was the melting of recrystallized urea, which, similar to a rigid matrix, could greatly suppress the nonradiative process.
The role of H-bonded matrices in RTP was demonstrated in a CDs@CA suspension.[69] The study of the PL mechanism indicated that there were CO, NH, and CN bonds on the surface of CDs, and the phosphorescence of CDs@CA powder might be due to CO bonds. Interestingly, the intensity of RTP was greatly enhanced in the presence of water, but not in other organic solvents, such as ethanol and acetone. As shown in Figure 7b, CA particle surfaces contained numerous polar groups, which was favorable for their adsorption of the ordered water molecules, which could further form hydrogen bonds with CDs. The bridge-like H-bonding system in CDs@ CA suspension could fix the CO bonds of CDs, and meanwhile improve the rigidity of the composite system, resulting in the strong phosphorescence in water.
The unique TADF behavior observed in CDs@zeolites composites also benefited from the important role of zeolitic host matrices.[45] A possible mechanism for generating TADF was proposed in Figure 7c. Study showed that the surface groups of CDs (e.g., CO or CN) enhanced the generation of triplet states through intersystem crossing. The zeolite matrices could greatly harvest the long-lived triplet states because the extensive dangling OH groups on the interrupted zeolitic matrix and the occluded templates could form complex H-bonds with CDs. The extensive H-bonding interactions could prevent the nonradiative relaxation of CDs and then stabilize the triplet state. Furthermore, the small ΔEST values of CDs@zeolite composites

(0.22 to 0.23 eV) enabled the possibility of reverse intersystem crossing (RISC), giving rise to TADF phenomenon.
Apart from the stabilizing effect of zeolitic matrices, the important role of heteroatoms doped in zeolites was first explored in CDs@Mn-LEV and CDs@Zn-CHA composites.[46] A donor– acceptor system could be constructed when Mn as heteroatoms in CDs@Mn-LEV composite. The spectral overlap occurred between the RTP emission of CDs and UV–vis spectrum of Mn-LEV, which afforded an efficient energy transfer between CDs and zeolite matrix, resulting in the interesting red RTP behavior. While in CDs@Zn-CHA composite, no influence of Zn heteroatoms has been found on the RTP property, CDs@Zn-CHA exhibits the green RTP coming from the zeolite-confined CDs.
The mechanism of PVA matrix-assisted triple-mode emission was revealed in the CDs@PVA composite (Figure 7d).[62] This study indicated that the PL and UCPL properties arose from the inherent characteristics of the as-prepared CDs, where UCPL was a two-photon excitation process as revealed
by the quadratic dependence between the NIR laser powers and emission intensities of CDs. The observed RTP emission was primarily related to the CN/CN bonds on the surface of CDs. In particular, the PVA matrix was a key factor for the RTP property because no phosphorescence was observed for CDs in water, PVA aqueous solution, or polymethyl methacrylate. The rich hydroxy functional groups of PVA could form H-bonds with CN/CN functional groups of CDs. The immobilization of CDs in the PVA matrix could stabilize the triplet state. Thus, the PVA matrix could effectively confine emissive species and restrict their intramolecular vibrations and rotations.
In summary, for TADF materials, the energy gaps (ΔEst) between the singlet state (S1) and the triplet state (T1) should be sufficiently small so that the nonradiative triplet excitons can transform into radiative singlet excitons through the RISC process.[44] For RTP materials, the efficient spin-orbit coupling should be acquired for triplet excitons by enhancing the ISC process, thus leading to larger energy gaps between S1 and

sections.heading: 5.1. Bioimaging and Drug Release
sections.text: CDs as fluorescent probes have various potential applications in bioimaging due to their excellent PL property and biocompatibility. Some host matrices, for example, mesoporous silica (mSiO2), can not only act as a nanoreactor to encapsulate CDs but can also carry drugs, so the resulting nanocomposites are promising candidates for cell imaging and drug release.[52] Figure 8 shows the process of doxorubicin (DOX) release from CDs@ mSiO2 in HeLa cells and then the accumulation in the nucleus. Briefly, a drug DOX was loaded onto CDs@mSiO2, and its release was monitored via the PL emission in different pH buffers. This study revealed that DOX in composites had a higher cellular toxicity than free DOX. In contrast to the passive diffusion process of free DOX, cell uptake of DOX@CDs@mSiO2 was via an active endocytosis process to induce the cell apoptosis.[104,105]

sections.heading: 5.2. Adsorption
sections.text: Taking advantage of the high surface area of the mesoporous silica and the PL property of CDs, CDs@SBA-NH2 nanocomposites exhibit a high efficiency for the selective adsorption of uranium, and the adsorption process can be in situ monitored via the fluorescence intensity of the nanocomposites.[54] The uranium adsorption of CDs@SBA-NH2 nanocomposite shows pH-dependent behavior, and the maximum adsorption capacity of 173.60 mg g−1 is achieved when pH = 5. The composites exhibit enhanced adsorption ability and higher adsorption selectivity for U(VI) over other competing metal ions compared with the SBA-NH2 precursor. Moreover, the nanocomposite shows the obvious fluorescent response to U(VI), and the fluorescence intensity decreases rapidly after the adsorption of U(VI).

sections.heading: 5.3. Sensor
sections.text:
CDs-based composites show a fluorescence sensing ability for temperature, metal ion, and pH detection. For example, as a temperature sensor, the luminescent intensity of CDs@UiO66(OH)2 at 464 nm decreases when the temperature increases from 25 to 110 °C, showing an excellent linear relationship.[44] In addition, CDs@UiO-66(OH)2 solution exhibits different fluorescence responses to pH value: the emission intensity is highest at a pH of 3.0, and decreases with the pH value

As a long-lived RTP material, the CDs@CA composite can be used as a sensor for detecting Fe3+ ions in water.[69] A static quenching process occurs in such fluorescence detecting, which may be due to the formation of a nonfluorescent complex between the CDs and Fe3+ ions. In complicated peptone solutions with various amino acids and proteins, the CDs@CA suspension can also effectively detect Fe3+ ions whereas CDs do not work as a better fluorescent sensor due to interference of scattered light and fluorescent organic species.

sections.heading: 5.4. Anticounterfeiting and Encryption
sections.text:
The unique RTP or TADF properties of CDs-based composite materials endow them with potential applications in advanced anticounterfeiting. The CDs@PVA composite has triple-mode emissions including PL, UCPL, and RTP.[62] A CDs@PVA
aqueous dispersion exhibits different colors in daylight (colorless) and under a UV lamp (bright cyan). Using the ink made by such a dispersion, the characters “heng” and “A” have been handwritten on a banknote. They are invisible in daylight. The bright blue characters (PL mode) can be observed together with the inherent anticounterfeiting mark (“100”) upon UV irradiation. The cyan characters (UCPL mode) are observed upon excitation with a femtosecond pulse laser. After the UV lamp is turned off, blue-green colored characters can also be seen by the naked eye (RTP mode), but the yellow number “100” disappears.
The multilevel fluorescence/phosphorescence data encryption is presented in the thermal-treatment controlled RTP CDs@PVA composites because of the different luminescence responses of composites annealed at different temperatures.[64] Such an encryption pattern is made using three types of composites (Figure 9a). The first level of encrypted characters “CD” is written by CD-2@PVA and the second level “CDots” is written by CD-1@PVA and CD-2@PVA. sections.heading: 6. Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
In summary, we have reviewed the recent research progress achieved in the CDs-based composite materials, including their synthesis, interesting luminescence properties, luminescence mechanism, and applications. The strategy of CDs-in-matrices has provided a broad platform for boosting novel luminescence properties and applications through the synergetic effects of guest CDs and host matrices. However, despite this, there remain problems and challenges need to be overcome in the future development of CDs-based composite materials.
First, the matrix materials used in the CDs-based composites remain limited. By now, the reported matrices are primarily focused on two classes: one is the nanoporous materials including zeolites, MOFs, and mesoporous materials that can confine CDs in the nanospaces, and the other is media materials including PVA and PU that can disperse CDs to form films. Developing new matrix materials may facilitate the discovery of more types of CDs-based composites. In particular, the matrices with the advantages of low cost, easy preparation, controllable functionalization, excellent chemical stability, and biocompatibility/nontoxicity, etc., are highly desired.
Second, the synthesis methods of CDs are versatile, and the precursors for preparing CDs are diverse; however, achieving uniform size, controllable structure, surface groups, and physiochemical properties of CDs remains difficult at the current synthesis level. Regarding the CDs-based composites, their complex synthesis compared with those of CDs brings more uncontrolled factors, such as the aggregation, the amount and distribution of CDs in a matrix, the interaction between CDs and the matrix, defects and so on. The ability for the rational design and fabrication of CDs-based composites with welldefined structures should be improved through the study and comparison of the structures (core, surface chemistry), sizes and luminescent properties of the composites obtained from different matrices and methodologies.
Third, CDs-based composites with a high quantum yield, long wavelength emission (particularly red emission), ultralong lifetime, chirality, and tunable luminescence properties remain underexplored. To this end, there needs to be a combination of the advantages of CDs and the host matrix, precise control/ predesign of the host matrix and CDs with desired functions and PL properties, promotion of the interactions and energy transfer between CDs and the matrix, and/or postmodification of the specific functional groups on CDs or the host matrix. In addition, the multifunctional luminescent composites are also a promising direction for material innovation of CDs-based composites.
Fourth, the luminescent mechanism of the CDs-based composite was not fully understood until now. This is because of the diversiform and still debatable luminescent mechanisms of CDs, the unclear structure features of CDs, and the complicated interactions between CDs and host matrices. Therefore, more efforts should be devoted to advanced and high-resolution
characterization techniques as well as to computational simulations, which may increase our understanding of structure– property relationships, the host–guest interactions, and the fundamental PL mechanisms.
Finally, for the practical application of CDs-based composites, there remains a long way to go although potential applications in bioimaging, drug delivery/release, sensing, and anticounterfeiting have been found. Thus, future research efforts should be directed to the development of more novel applications in the fields of biology, catalysis, optical electronics, and energy storage and conversion. In addition, the large-scale fabrication of CDs-based composites still needs to be achieved to fully realize their practical application. With the continued advances of experimental and theoretical studies, we can expect to find more novel and practical applications for CDs-based composites in the future.
